list_items: Review of G1-3 skills
$\succ$  Grade 4 skills
\* Grade 5 skills
- Parts of speech P4-6
- Pronouns P7-11
- Prepositions-in, on, at; time, place and cause; cause P12- 14
- Subject-verb agreement- to be; has/ have; is/are P15- 19
- General verb agreement (easy to challenging) P20-21
Verb agreement with collective and abstract nouns P22
Future tense P23- 24
Irregular past tense verbs P25- 28
- Modal verbs P29-30
$\succ$  Conditional tenses P31- 36
- Comparative and superlative adjectives P37- 39
$\succ$  Present progressive P40
$\succ$  Past progressive P41- 42
$\succ$  Past participles P43- 45
$\triangleright$  Present perfect P46- 47
$\succ$  Past perfect P48- 49
$\triangleright$  Clause awareness P50-52

table_body:
Part of SpeechFunctionExample WordsExample Sentence
nounperson, animal or thingdog, pen, England, man, carrot, TomAffah lives with his dog and cat in London.
verbaction, state or occurrencehave, happen, be, bring, head, walk, danceJane must study hard and learn well.
adjectivedescribes a nounbeautiful, big, red, fruity, interestingThe little girl loves her old ragged doll.
pronounreplaces a nounI, you, he, she, we, they, it, someShe want to the shops with him. They had fun.
adverbdescribes a verb, adjective, adverb, etc.slowly, happily, incredibly, truly, kindlyAlice and Jim sometimes run quickly together.
prepositionin situ a noun to another worddown, from, into, like, near, on, under upMy dog is lying down, next to me on the floor.
conjunctionjoins words, phrases or clausesfor, and, but, or, yet, so, norI like bears and lions, but I don't like cats or dogs.
interjectionword or short phrase that conveys emotionoh, you, they, well, turn, high, holdOh, that hurt oh no, it's my knees stop! Opps!
determinerintroduces a nounthat, my, these, his, a couple, theThe boy supported his local team.

text: We use nouns to name things. However, if we use the same nouns too much, our writing becomes awkward and lacks cohesion. To avoid this happening, we can use pronouns.
There are personal and possessive pronouns.

Personal pronouns replace the names of people or things. They can take the form of 'singular' pronouns - just one person or thing. They can also take the form of 'plural' pronouns - more than one person or thing.
Possessive pronouns replace the people or things that have or own something. They can also take the form of singular and plural, i.e. just one or more than one.
Complete the sentences by choosing the correct pronoun.
a) My sister bought a new coat last week. That coat is hers.
b) Matt is a brilliant footballer. We are so proud of him.
c) Tom broke my pen so he bought me a new one.
d) They were happy that their bus had finally arrived.
e) My friend, Zina, is over there. Can you see her?
3. Copy the paragraph below, replacing the underlined words with appropriate pronouns.

Sienna and Paul went to the park. Sienna went on the swings first and after, Sienna went on the roundabout but fell off and grazed Sienna's knee. Paul played in the sandpit. Paul built a sandcastle and even made a moat for Paul's sandcastle. Sienna and Paul played on the climbing frame together. Sienna and Paul enjoyed chasing each other until home time.

LO: I can recognise and name verbs, nouns, adjectives, adverbs, conjunctions and prepositions.

text: The children are teaching themselves Spanish.
You are going to enjoy yourself at the fair.
Write sentences for these reflexive pronouns
Time prepositions tell us when something happens.
at - used with a specific time, a clock time.
on - used with a day or date.
e.g. On Tuesday it was sunny.
in - used for long periods of time, like a month, a year, etc.
e.g. In June we'll go on holiday.
Task 1: Identify the time preposition in each sentence and write it below.

list_items: 1. We went to the cinema at eight o'clock.
2. We went on our holidays in July.
3. It always snows in Winter.
4. In September, we will go back to school.
5. We have our spelling test on Friday morning.

text: Task 3: Choose the correct time preposition for each of the following sentences.

list_items: 1. I built a sandcastle on the beach.
2. We go to bed every night 7:30 pm.
3. Frey Christmas day, we visit our grandparents and cousins.
4. We are getting our Summer holidays in two months.
5. I have gymnastics training at 4 o'clock.
6. I will be going shopping Friday.

text: Prepositions for time, place and cause

In each of the sentences below, underline the word that is the preposition. Then try and identify if the preposition shows time, place or cause by writing each one of these words in the box provided. The first one has been done for you.

list_items: 1. The squirrel sat on the branch.
2. After football training, I went home.
3. The tennis match was cancelled due to the bad weather.
4. There was a celebration in honour of the Queen.
5. At 12 o'clock, the children have their lunch.
6. The car was parked opposite the shop.
7. There was a fire drill during our English lesson.
8. Since yesterday, I have felt very ill.
9. The dog stood between his owners.

4. the support of all the sponsors, the church raised enough money to fix the roof.

text: I can use the different present tense forms of the verb 'to have'.
The present tense forms of the verb 'to have' are has and have.
1: Can you write the correct present form of 'to have' in these singular and plural sentences?

list_items: a. Jose have two pet parrots.
b. The company have twenty members of staff.
c. I _____ has _____ a badly-broken arm.
d. The rabbits hws a new hutch in the garden.
e. Jonathan fantastic football skills.

text: 2. Can you add the correct form of the verb 'to have' when it is used as an auxiliary verb before extending these sentences?

list_items: a. I peeled the potatoes so
b. The fisherman caught a huge haul of fish as

text: c. The dog _____ a very sore paw because

Hi Grandma, I has not been around today because I has a really bad cold. I would has hated for you to has caught it from me. I think Susie have given it me as she was ill last week which caused her to has a day off school. Anyway, I has asked Dad to drop me at your house on Thursday if I has recovered. See u soon, Darcie x

text: Subject-verb agreement where the sentence is interrupted by a subordinate clause
Read and correct the following sentences:

list_items: 1. Downloads, which are categorised by genre, has increased by  $20\%$ .
2. The new track by Justin Timberlake, who is my mum's favourite artist, are popular.
3. The man, despite his swollen ankle, complete the race.

text: Now, rewrite these sentences and insert the correct verb form (in the present tense) to agree with the subject:

list_items: 6. The Paralympians who (to be) featured in the article (to train) for five hours a day.
7. Unless consumers, by which I mean all of us, (to take) action, there will be an environmental disaster.

text: Subject-verb agreement for collective and abstract nouns
B. Sometimes, we have to think more carefully about whether the subject is singular or plural.
For example, there may be a list of singular nouns. If there is more than one, then the verb needs to be plural:
Ana, Theo, Mo and Jing goes to the concert.  $\times$
Ana, Theo, Mo and Jing go to the concert.
Collective nouns are words which denote a group of things. For example, class, family, group.
Abstract nouns denote ideas, qualities or states - things that are uncountable.
Sometimes, the subject might be a collective noun, so although it might sound plural, it
Finally, abstract nouns are also always singular:
Read and correct the following sentences:

list_items: 1. Skyla, Dan, Sian and Mae leaves the car.
2. Unfortunately, the family are too late to get a discount.
3. The peace are shattered by the sound of shouting.
4. The class misbehave in assembly.
5. I think my phone, tablet, jewellery and bag is missing.

text: Simple Future is also known as Future Simple and describes events which will take place.
Future Continuous is also known as Future Progressive and describes events which will take place, over time.
Change these sentences to future tense.
1. The koala slept during the day.
2. We are working very hard to clean the kitchen up.
We very hard to clean the kitchen up.
3. My friends and I had a great time at the party.
My friends and I a great time at the party.
4. The birthday cake tasted deliciously sweet and rich.
The birthday cake deliciously sweet and rich.
5. The bird is flying high above the trees.
The bird high above the trees.
6. My online shopping order was delivered this afternoon.
My online shopping order delivered this afternoon.
7. I went to the AFL grand final game!
I to the AFL grand final game!
8. I am riding my bike to school this morning.
I my bike to school this morning.
Write 2 of your own future tense sentences:

6. She forgotten to close the back door.
7. We swimm ed at the beach yesterday.
8. The team built a remote control robot.
9. I steeped on the plane trip last week.
10. My parents meted when they were in college.

text: Regular and Irregular Verbs in Sentences
Use the list of present tense verbs below to work out the past tense verb that fits into each sentence.
1. I for the test last night.
2. On the weekend I ______ football in the park
3. Last week I a letter to my friend.
4. Last night for dinner, I ________ steak and chips with vegetables.
5. My mum when I gave her my surprise.
6. Last weekend, I to the movies with my friends.
7. When I was at the shops I my teacher from school.
8. On the way to school I _______ to my favourite band.
9. Last night, I ________ my homework after dinner.
10. Today during art, I ________ my best artwork ever!
11. Last weekend I ______ a sleepover with my friends.
12. I went to my first camp, and I ________ it.
14. I got in trouble yesterday because I my mums favourite vase
15. When I got home from soccer, I ________ my dad a message to tell him I was home.
16. On the weekend, my sister ______ the whole house from top to bottom!
17. My mum let me stay up late and I ______ the end of the TV show.
18. He going to let me join the game before I got angry.
Modal verbs have lots of uses. They can be used to:
to talk about habits and ability.
Choose a modal verb from the box to make each sentence make sense.

list_items: 1. We go to the zoo at the weekend.
2. I brush my teeth before I go to bed.
3. "we go to the park after school today please?"
4. When you get in the car, you ________ put your seatbelt on.
5. It looks like it ______ rain tomorrow.
6. ________ we pick up some dinner on the way home? suggested Mum.
7. "What you like to drink?" asked Ali.
8. "It's getting late; I think we _______ to go home."

10. I always finish my homework tomorrow.

text: Choose a modal verb and use it accurately in a sentence.
Can you use two in a sentence?
Can you start your sentence with a modal verb?
If we work hard, we will finish the project on time.
The first conditional is used to express a real or very probable situation in the future. It refers to things that will possibly happen in the future if a condition is met.
The first conditional is common when we are talking about possible plans, promises, warnings, threats or for persuading someone.

list_items: If I go to Italy next week for work, I'll visit the Colosseum.
If I have time tomorrow, I will help you.
If you touch that wire, you will get an electric shock.

text: Change the verb in the parenthesis ( ) to the correct form and write it in the space to make a first conditional tense sentence.

list_items: 1. If you (not pass) your exams, your parents (be) angry with you.
2. You (get) fat if you (eat) hamburgers every day.
3. If you (not help) me with the housework, I (not help) you with your homework.
4. If you (meet) your friends this evening, where do you ? (go)
5. I (stay) at home if it (rain) tomorrow.
6. If the weather (be) nice tomorrow, we (go) to the zoo.
7. Helen (put on) her favourite dress if she (go) out tonight.
8. If my mother (ask) me to help her with the housework, I (tell) her I have got a terrible headache.
9. If I (tell) my mother I have got a terrible headache, we (go) to the doctor.
10. If we (go) to the doctor, my mum (find out) that the headache was only an excuse.

text: Second Conditional tense is used when we talk about something imaginary that we are imagining happening.
Remember: we can make the second conditional in two ways:

Let's do some creative sentence writing. Imagine some impossible things and write 5 or 6 sentences using second conditional. e.g.- If I had a unicorn, I would ride it to school every day. I would wish for a mansion if I had 3 wishes from a genie.
"If I had been a firefighter, I would have driven a fire truck."
This is the 3rd conditional. We use it to talk about an imaginary past situation: something that didn't happen.
If  $^+$  past perfect would  $\clubsuit$  have  $^+$  past participles. If I had been a firefighter, I would have driven a fire true
would + have + past participle if + past perfect I would have driven a fire truck if I had been a firefighter
Use your ideas to complete these sentences. Be creative!

list_items: 1. If I had been born 100 years ago,
2. If I had been born in the times of the dinosaurs,
3. If we had never invented cars,
4. If I had never studied English,
5. If humans had never been to the moon,

text: We can make a zero conditional sentence with two present simple verbs (one in the 'if clause' and one in the 'main clause'):

This conditional is used when the result will always happen. So, if water reaches 100 degrees, it always boils. It's a fact. I'm talking in general, not about one particular situation. The result of the 'if clause' is always the main clause.
The 'if' in this conditional can usually be replaced by 'when' without changing the meaning.
For example: If water reaches 100 degrees, it boils. (It is always true, there can't be a different result sometimes).
If you touch a fire, you get burned.
People die if they don't eat.
You get water if you mix hydrogen and oxygen.
If babies are hungry, they cry.
Use the words to make sentences in Zero Conditional Tense.
If it doesn't rain, the flowers die.

list_items: 1. (I / wake up late / I / be late for work)
2. (my husband / cook / he / burn the food)
3. (Julie / not wear a hat / she / get sunstroke)
4. (children / not eat well / they / not be healthy)
5. (you / mix water and electricity / you / get a shock)
6. (people / eat / too many sweets / they / get fat)
7. (you / smoke / you / get yellow fingers)
8. (children / play outside / they / not get overweight)
9. (you / heat ice / it / melt)
10. (I / speak to John / he / get annoyed)

text: Comparative adjectives are usually made by adding -er to the end of an adjective. E.g- faster. Sometimes we need to change the y to an i. e.g- happier. Sometimes we need to double the final consonant. E.g- wetter. If the adjective ends with e, we need to take it away before adding -er. E.g- larger. Some adjectives change completely in comparative form e.g- bad changes to worse.

Superlative adjectives are usually made by adding -est to the end of an adjective e.g. - fastest. Sometimes we need to change the y to and i. e.g. - happiest. Sometimes we need to double the final consonant. E.g. wettest. If the adjective ends with e, we need to take it away before adding -est. E.g. largest. Some adjectives change completely in superlative form. E.g. bad changes to worst.
Let's try some exercises. Decide if the adjective should be comparative -er ending or superlative -est ending to make the sentence make sense.
When a two-syllable adjective ends in  $y$ , drop the  $y$  and add an  $i$  before adding the suffix. Complete these sentences:

list_items: 1. Jenny is the ______ girl in the world. pretty

2. My dad makes the _______ jokes.  
witty
3. My pet rat is than my cat. tiny
4. I'm when I'm at home. happy

text: Remember that for some words we double the end consonant before adding the suffix. Complete these sentences:

list_items: 1. It is today than yesterday. wet
2. He is the person around. mad
3. That is the cat I've ever seen! big
4. The road is than the grass. flat

text: When an adjective ends in the letter 'e', drop the 'e' before adding '-er' or '-est'. Complete these sentences using the word provided.

list_items: 1. My cat is cuter than your dog. cute
2. The sky is bluer than the sea. blue
3. My grandma has the strangest habits. strange
4. You will get wiser as you get older. wise

text: These common adjectives are irregular. The comparative and
superlative forms are different from the adjective.
Complete these sentences with the correct word from the table.

list_items: 1. I will do on the test if I study hard.
2. I have the ______ cookies out of all my friends. It's not fair!
3. Sarah earns ______ money than Fred. Sarah is richer.
4. I have the _______ marks in the class on the maths test because I studied really hard.

text: Write your own sentences with comparative or superlative adjectives.
Present progressive is used to show that something is still happening. We need to use the verb 'to be' and the action verb with -ing on the end.
e.g.- I am listening to music.

list_items: 1. I TV now. (watch)
2. My mum banana cakes. (bake)
3. The cat under the table. (sleep)
4. The birds in the sky. (fly)
5. We ______ lunch. (have)
6. The boy his bicycle. (ride)
7. My sister her hands. (clap)
8. My friends some apple juice. (drink)
9. They badminton. (play)

text: 10. Bob and Kate in the sea. (swim)
Past progressive is used to show an event that was happening in the past. It uses the past tense form of the verb 'to be' and the action verb with an ing ending.
e.g.- The cat was sitting on the mat.
The children were chatting in class.
Finish the sentences using the Past Progressive Tense.

list_items: a) When the doctor came, she
b) Before he went to sleep, he
c) To impress his mum, he

text: Use the Past Progressive Tense to describe three things you were doing when you were one year old.
2. Change these sentences from past progressive tense to present progressive tense and vice versa.

table_body:
Past Progressive TensePresent Progressive Tense
They were milking the cows.
He is looking for somewhere to live.
She is turning the car around.
It was coming closer all the time.

text: Knowing the base verbs (also called infinitives) and past participles of verbs is very important.
Base verbs or infinitive verbs are used when we write imperative or bossy sentences. E.g- Be
They are also used when we use the words want, have or like with an other verb. E.g- I like to
Or when we are also using a modal verb in the sentence. E.g. You must keep this a secret.
We use past participles when we are writing in present perfect tense and past perfect tense
e.g. I have bought a new computer so that I can do my work.
e.g. I had bought a new computer before the meeting so that I could do the work.
They are also used to create passive voice sentences. E.g My homework was eaten by my dog.
We use them in past tense sentences that use a modal verb. E.g. - You should have gone to

list_items: 1. Create a matching game using the verbs in the table below. Test yourself and your friends.
2- With a partner, take turns to pick a verb from the table and say a sentence using that word.
3- Write sentences using the base words and past participles.

text: We use present perfect tense when we want to express an unfinished period of
time- an event that started in the past but is still relevant now.
e.g- I have grown flowers for 2 years and still grow them now.
Remember to use the past participle list above to help you.
We form the present perfect by using the auxiliary verb before the past participle of the main verb.

Use the substitution table below to help you complete the sentences using the present perfect tense. For each sentence, you will need to choose either 'have' or 'has' and the past participle of the verb so that each sentence makes sense.

It

text: Underline the verb form that is the present perfect in the passage below.

Annie enjoys climbing trees in her garden and has made a swing that dangles from one of the branches, with the help of her mum. She was crossing her fingers that there would be time to start making a real tree house, but the weekend disappeared. Annie was so pleased to have an adult to tie the knots.
Write a sentence in the present perfect below.

Past perfect tense is used when we are talking about 2 events that both happened in the past. E.g- He had eaten all of the cake before she arrived home. Past perfect is formed with the verb had and the past participle of the verb. Use the past participle list to help you with this work.
Complete the sentences using Past perfect tense.

list_items: 1. The fire had already (already/reach) the roof by the time the firemen arrived.
2.- Joe Smith went to prison because he (steal) a lot of money.
3.-Helen went to bed after she (watch) her favourite TV programme.
4.-My father bought the new car after he (try) it a few times.
5.-By the time Sonia got to the party, everyone (begin) dancing.
6.-Lorenzo (eat) all the ice cream before I opened the fridge.
7. There was a lot of snow outside because it (snow) earlier in that day.
8.-Beatrix didn't pass the test because she (not study) at all.
9.-Look!Somebody (leave) the windows open.
10.-By the time the police arrived, the burglar (break) into my neighbour's house.

text: Write 4 sentences in present perfect tense.
e.g.- I have made a cake for your birthday.
Write 5 sentences in past perfect tense.
e.g. I had been watching TV when my mum told me to get on with my homework.
When we write complex sentences we usually have a main clause part of our sentence and a subordinate clause part of our sentence.
Main clause (also called independent clause)- The main clause is a whole sentence that makes sense by itself.
Subordinate clause (also called sub-clause or dependent clause)- The subordinate clause does not make sense by itself. It is not a complete sentence.
The subordinate clause can be at the beginning, middle or end of the sentence.
Here are some examples. The main clause is underlined.
Although I was scared, I crept inside the abandoned house.
The girl, who had red hair, strolled through the forest.
James wore the new trainers that his grandad had bought for him.
Task- Underline the main clause in these sentences:

list_items: 1- Despite the cold weather, Fred enjoyed the football match.
2- When it is sunny, we need to wear sunscreen.
3- The dog, who had been at the animal shelter for 2 years, was finally adopted.
4- I ate the delicious food that my mum made for me.
5- Running swiftly, she tried to escape from the monster.

text: Can you extend these sentences by adding a subordinate clause at the beginning, in the middle and at the end? You can choose a different subordinate clause for each variation.
Katy took a deep breath and blew out her candles. After we sang Happy Birthday, Katy took a deep breath and blew out her candles.
Katy, who was 9-years-old today, took a deep breath and blew out her candles.
Katy took a deep breath and blew out her candles before we cut into the cake.
I think it's my turn to do the

Existing sentenceExtended sentences

text: One way to make a complex sentence is to use a subordinating conjunction. Here are some subordinating conjunctions that we often use.
Fill the gaps with one of the subordinating conjunctions above to make the sentence make sense.

list_items: 1- it snows, I wear my snow-oots outside.
2- I read a book my sister played a video game.
3- You cannot play on your Nintendo Switch ______ you have completed your homework.
4- it is raining outside, I will take my umbrella I go out.
5- I will go to the party tomorrow my friend is going.

image_caption: Use your super sentence writing skills to create a complex (multi-clause) sentence using different subordinating conjunctions. Read the main clause on the puzzle pieces, add an appropriate subordinating conjunction and then add your own subordinate clause. The first one is done for you as an example.

text: Using a fronted adverbial is another way to make a complex sentence.
Fronted adverbials go at the start of a sentence to add details to the main clause.
Here are some different types of fronted adverbial.
Writing Your Own Fronted Adverbials: ISPACE
Using ISPACE can help you remember six different ways to create frontal adverbials.
e.g. After he opened his eyes, ...

list_items: - Shaking with fear, he stared up at the towering monster.
-Like a raging bull, she charged at the bully.
-Behind the clouds, there was a giant castle.
- Anxiously, she waited for her turn to take the test.
-After he opened his eyes, he realised that he had been dreaming.

text: -Exhausted, the dog flopped down onto the grass.
1. Tick all the sentences that contain a fronted adverbial.
Walking across the field, the children became very muddy.
It was great fun doing the washing up.
Her mum works in an office.
Standing by Emma, Jack hopped on one leg.
2. Make three fronted adverbial sentences from the blue and orange tiles. Your sentences must make sense.

table_body:
After that,As quickly as possible,Without reason,
In the morning,Back at the house,Unexpectedly,
Fortunately,Once a year,While I was waiting,

I tried again.we are going to the seaside.my computer screen turned off.
Dad was cleaning the kitchen.we celebrate Christmas.she reappeared right in front of us.
I checked my coat pocket and my lunch money was there.she tan back from school.I drew a picture in my journal.

text: 3. Underline the adverbials, circle the verbs.
Before the sun came up, he ate his breakfast.
As fast as he could, the rabbit hopped.
4. Insert the comma in the correct place to demarcate the fronted adverbial.
Before the sun came up she stood and waited.
In the dead of night the black cat began to wake.
Throughout the film my sister talked on her phone.
Positively trembling with excitement he accepted the award.
Unfortunately they arrived after the film had started.
In the blink of an eye the magician was gone.
Another way to make a complex sentence is to use a relative clause. To do this we use a relative pronoun to add detail to the sentence. Relative pronouns are: which, who, whose, where, when.
e.g. The girl, who had forgotten her umbrella, got very wet in the rain.
The sentences below have been mixed up! Please match the main clause to the relative clause that suits it best. For example:

table_body:
My favourite food is pizza,which originates from Italy.
My favourite food is pizza,which is made from snow.

Main Clauses
I go swimming at 7am,
Robert is a very hardworking boy,
I can't eat the sandwich because it has peanut butter inside it,
My sister looks like my mum,
We moved house in 2014,
Jaguars live in the rainforest,
The Egyptians were great architects,
I have to play inside the house,
The flying boy is called Peter Pan,

Relative Clauses
whose hair curls in the same way.
which I am allergic to.
when I was 8 years old.
who always does his homework.
when the weather is terrible outside.
who built many pyramids.
where it is hot and humid.
which means I don't have breakfast until 8.30 am.
whose home is in Neverland.

text: Emma likes to write songs and has written some sentences for her new song. However, she thinks the sentences are too short for the music and would like to combine them to make longer, complex sentences. Help her to make two sentences become one by changing the pronoun in the second sentence into a relative pronoun and joining the two together (remember to add a comma before the relative pronoun). For example:

Mrs Smith was my teacher. She taught me in Year 2.  
Mrs Smith was my teacher, who taught me in Year 2.
Use these relative pronouns to help you:

list_items: 1. I like to eat pizza. It's my favourite food.
2. My alarm broke this morning. This meant I was late for school.
3. My best friends are Mel and Victoria. They walk with me to school.
4. I started school in reception class. I was four years old.
5. I have a friend called Geri. Her house is next door to mine.
6. I eat in the hall. It's always very noisy.
7. My principal is Mr Johnson. He has a friendly smile.

text: Relative clauses can also be 'dropped in' (or embedded) into the middle of sentence after the noun it is giving extra information about. For example:
Luke, who is very sporty, likes to play football.

In the example above, the relative clause has been placed in the middle of the sentence after the noun 'Luke' who it gives more information about. Think of it as a cheeseburger. The relative clause is the meat that fills the middle of the bun and the bun is the main clause. Complete the cheeseburgers below by adding an embedded clause to the burger.
Continue to add relative clauses to the middle of these cheeseburgers but this time choose your own relative pronoun to complete the sentence.

We use passive voice when we want our writing to sound more formal. In passive voice the subject of the sentence is having something done to it/ them. This is different from active voice (what we normally use) where the subject of the sentence is doing the action.

table_body:
Active voiceThe dog bit me.
Passive voiceI was bitten by the dog.

text: When we write in passive voice we need to use the verb to be the past participle of the verb. E.g- was bitten.
Often a passive voice sentence uses 'by' to show who or what is doing the action.

table_body:
VerbActivePassive
The school arranged a visit.
A visit was arranged by the school.
The dog buried the bone.
The bone was buried by the dog.
The man painted the wall.
The wall was painted by the man.
The ball was thrown at the window by the naughty girl.
The naughty girl threw the ball at the window.
You must not run across the road.
You could get run over!

text: Now change the following active sentences to passive.

list_items: 1. Simon Cowell glared at the X Factor contestant.
2. The year 6 children run a tuck shop.
3. Your cat took the last biscuit.
4. Mrs Tellman organised a theatre trip.
5. The tiger gnawed at the bone.

text: Complete the following table, inserting a tick showing whether the verb is active or passive.
Write 5 of your own sentences using passive voice
